10:35 <lucaa> has joined #xwiki  
10:39 <+mflorea> guys, how do you feel about retiring xwiki-web-gwt. It hasn't been maintained and afaik it isn't used in the standard distribution. WDYT?  
10:42 <+mflorea> lucaa: xwiki watch depends on xwiki-web-gwt right?  
10:46 <+lucaa> mflorea: yes, iirc  
10:47 <+mflorea> so I guess it's going to be hard to make it work on 3.0 if I remove it, right?  
10:47 <+mflorea> I mean, there's not way you can bundle it  
10:48 <+lucaa> well, it needs the servlet, right? and then some client side code, but the client side code is compiled with watch  
10:48 <+lucaa> right?  
10:48 <+mflorea> yes, the servlet mapping from web.xml is the issue, if I remove it from the standard web.xml then you'll have to add it manually  
10:49 <abusenius\_> has joined #xwiki  
10:49 <abusenius\_> is now known as <abusenius>  
10:50 <+lucaa> well, watch has a service of it's own now as well  
10:50 <+lucaa> which needs to be put in web.xml  
10:50 <+tmortagne> mflorea: is this project really useless ? I'm not sure what is it exactly but its name sounds like a generic GWT stuff, i tough WYSIWYG was depending on it actually  
10:50 <+lucaa> when installing watch  
10:51 <+lucaa> so since watch install is modifying web.xml it might as well add this...  
10:51 <+lucaa> but I think there are some applications on extensions that use this api  
10:51 <+mflorea> tmortagne: this module was written mainly for curriki, the WYSIWYG editor doesn't depend on it. It isn't generic and it isn't maintained  
10:52 <+tmortagne> +1 then  
10:52 <+lucaa> for example, there's a table cell edit application or something, which will not work without this api  
10:52 <+mflorea> lucaa: do you know which other apps depend on it?  
10:52 <+lucaa> lemme see if I can find this fast  
10:53 <+tmortagne> we can probably document in the extension page that since 3.0 it also needs to install some server side stuff  
10:53 <+tmortagne> got from an older release in maven.xwiki.org  
10:53 <+lucaa> well, the only issue I see with removing it is that it will be really unmaintained  
10:54 <+lucaa> I mean, not even compiled  
10:54 <+lucaa> with the platform  
10:54 <+tmortagne> there is already compiled versions  
10:54 <+lucaa> which means that potentially an API change can break this and we won't even know it  
10:54 <+tmortagne> if it's not maintained it's probably already broken someway  
10:54 <+lucaa> well, at least it compiles  
10:55 <+lucaa> which we don't guarantee if we take it out of platform  
10:55 <+tmortagne> sure but we don't remove APIs usually  
10:55 <+tmortagne> we have plugin that use the same API since ages and still not broken  
10:55 <+lucaa> and we cannot say that: "you need to install this from here" to have watch working, since we cannot guarantee it would at least compile  
10:55 <+tmortagne> could be moved in watch sources  
10:56 <+lucaa> tmortagne: thanks, and I get to support it :D  
10:56 <+tmortagne> O:-)  
10:56 <+lucaa> well, the thing is, if we wanna rely on the fact that we don't remove API, we need to audit this module first to make sure that it's only using API  
10:56 <+lucaa> which I cannot guarantee as we speak  
10:57 <+tmortagne> i'm not talking about public API, even protected XWiki api is usually not broken, either it goes to aspect or xwiki-legacy  
10:57 <+tmortagne> plugin don't use public API  
10:57 <+tmortagne> not much at least  
10:59 <+mflorea> lucaa, besides compiling the code you'd have to compile the gwt code to be sure it works with the current gwt version, which doesn't happen. i.e. right only only the jar is generated  
10:59 <vmassol> guys for fun I've created a jira filter that lists all issues fixed in XE 3.0 (till 3.0M3 included): http://jira.xwiki.org/jira/secure/IssueNavigator.jspa?mode=hide&requestId=10820  
10:59 <vmassol> 352 issues  
10:59 <+mflorea> so you can have the surprise that xwiki-web-gwt doesn't actually work, even if it compiles  
10:59 <vmassol> (for the future we need to generate it)

11:18 <+mflorea> it is generated by maven jar plugin  
11:18 <vmassol> mflorea: plugin-api is missing a packaging tab IMO  
11:18 <vmassol> mflorea: not really  
11:18 <+mflorea> jar is by default  
11:18 <vmassol> no  
11:18 <vmassol> the default is to use the parent's  
11:19 <+mflorea> it works for me  
11:19 <vmassol> (AFAIR)  
11:19 <+mflorea> no  
11:19 <vmassol> you should always put it  
11:19 <vmassol> always always  
11:19 <+tmortagne> vmassol: not for packaging  
11:19 <+tmortagne> jar is default packaging  
11:19 <+mflorea> I tested this explicitly and it doesn't take the packaging of the parent  
11:19 <vmassol> I repeat you shoudl always put it  
11:19 <+mflorea> no  
11:19 <+mflorea> why?  
11:19 <+mflorea> it's redundant  
11:19 <+tmortagne> but i agree it's nicer to explicitely set it  
11:19 <vmassol> because it's important info and we don't want to rely on a behavior that can change  
11:20 <+tmortagne> never know, ther eis no technical reason for it to be the default and maybe maven will change one day  
11:20 <vmassol> and I don't trust tools  
11:20 <vmassol> (to correctly extrapolate it)  
11:20 <+mflorea> they why not specify all defaults?  
11:20 <+mflorea> like value, groupId  
11:20 <vmassol> they're not all important details  
11:20 <+mflorea> s/value/version  
11:20 <vmassol> what is value?  
11:20 <+tmortagne> groupId is not default  
11:20 <+tmortagne> it's inherited  
11:20 <+tmortagne> it's not the same  
11:20 <+mflorea> yes, but this is the current behavior  
11:20 <+tmortagne> same for version  
11:20 <vmassol> version is to not have to repeat it for maintainance  
11:21 <+mflorea> could be change, "I don't trust tools"  
11:21 <vmassol> mflorea: the onyl fact that we're talking about it  
11:21 <vmassol> justifies that it needs to be there  
11:21 <vmassol> :)  
11:21 <vmassol> since we didn't have the same understanding  
11:21 <vmassol> about it  
11:21 <vmassol> so it's not obvious  
11:22 <vmassol> and  
11:22 <vmassol> this is what we do everywhere already  
11:22 <vmassol> I don't see why we would add ane xception just for this modul  
11:22 <+tmortagne> vmassol: should be checked before saying things like that ;)  
11:22 <vmassol> yeah but then they're "bugs"  
11:22 <vmassol> that we should fix too  
11:22 <vmassol> all I remember have it  
11:22 <+mflorea> this doesn't justify a bad practice  
11:23 <+mflorea> IMO, generally speaking, default values should be explicitly written down  
11:24 <vmassol> mflorea: you prefer to remove all packaging in all modules?  
11:24 <vmassol> (all modules thar are jars)  
11:24 <+mflorea> yes  
11:24 <vmassol> right now I haven't seen anywhere on the web this  
11:24 <vmassol> but I have seen the opposite  
11:25 <vmassol> trying to find some best practice page  
11:25 <vmassol> btw jar being the default is objectable  
11:25 <+tmortagne> IMO the packaging is not like anything else, the fact that jar is the default in maven right now is something totally arbitrary since a maven repository does not really have anything to do with java, it could contains anything  
11:26 <+mflorea> ok, I'll add the packing info  
11:26 <+tmortagne> it has nothing to do with something you would inherit  
11:27 <vmassol> back to trying to understand why the build fails  
11:27 <vmassol> mflorea: test-jar doesn't generate "tests" qualifier AFAIK  
11:28 <vmassol> http://maven.apache.org/guides/mini/guide-attached-tests.html  
11:28 <+mflorea> I have the jar in my target directory  
11:28 <vmassol> it generates test-jar  
11:28 <+mflorea> and no working on my log  
11:28 <vmassol> not "tests"  
11:29 <+mflorea> vmassol: I have the jar in my target dir  
11:29 <+mflorea> -tests.jar  
11:29 <+tmortagne> vmassol: actually yes it does see http://maven.xwiki.org/releases/org/xwiki/enterprise/xwiki-enterprise-test-selenium/3.0-milestone-3/  
11:29 <+tmortagne> for example  
11:30 <vmassol> I've never used that and i don't think the doc is wrong  
11:30 <vmassol> checking something  
11:30 <+tmortagne> but you are supposed to depends on it using <type>test-jar</type>  
11:30 <jstoldt> hi  
11:30 <+tmortagne> vmassol: the doc is not wrong  
11:31 <+tmortagne> but <type> is not the same as <classifier>  
11:31 <+mflorea> I used <classifier>tests</classifier> and it works  
11:31 <vmassol> tmortagne: right  
11:31 <+tmortagne> mflorea: don't use classifier  
11:31 <vmassol> you should use type and not classifier  
11:31 <+mflorea> why?  
11:32 <vmassol> because you're using the jar plugin  
11:32 <+tmortagne> since you don't explicitely define the test jar as being of classifier "tests" and that could be changed  
11:32 <vmassol> and that's how it's supposed to work  
11:32 <vmassol> mflorea: please read the doc  
11:32 <vmassol> (the one I sent)  
11:32 <vmassol> "Note that previous editions of this guide suggested to use <classifier>tests</classifier> instead of <type>test-jar</type>. While this currently works for some cases, it does not properly work during a reactor build of the test JAR module and any consumer if a lifecycle phase prior to install is invoked. In such a scenario, Maven will not resolve the test JAR from the output of the reactor build but from the local/remote repository. Ap  
11:32 <+mflorea> ok
